Can I have a beer?  After getting her beer, Vi turns around and suddenly notices Mr Scott, who is sitting alone. She goes over to him.

I have so much respect for you.

And I mean, really good word choices. It kind of reminded me a little of Faulkner, but East Coast and disabled.

It was completely racist, and beyond that I felt deeply offended as a 	woman. As if a woman can only operate from experiences of objectification.
And so weirdly misogynistic. I mean, why does Jane go through with this? Is she stupid?

in fact, it actually approaches a level of grotesquerie. Ad your subtitle, 'the rawness of truth' is that supposed to be a joke of some sort? Or are you just being pretentious?

I don't know about 'what happened,' Vi, because once you start writing, it  all becomes fiction. Still, it certainly is an improvement over your last story: There is now at least a beginning, a middle, and an end.
What are you gonna do now?
Toby -? Oh, hi! How are you?

So. Look at where we are: the year 2000! Can you believe it? I mean, did you ever think we would actually make it?
Oh, no, not any more. No, um, I kind of came to terms with myself, I realized I had done what I had to do. And it was time to move on.
Well, I went to law school, if you can believe that.
Yeah, well, then it got me writing, so that was a good thing.
Well, um, I kind of let things go on this novel I'd been really into - I mean, the whole publishing industry is totally corrupt. I mean, really, it's finished.
N-not yet. I'm hoping to get a grant for this one project on teenagers. Geez, remember when we were teenagers?

Uh, well, anyway, so I'm looking for subjects for this documentary on teenage life in suburbia. Kind of an exploration of the mental psyche of its mythology. I wrote to Derrida to see if he'd like to do the narration. But everything's still kind of in development at this point.
I work in a shoe store right now. But it's cool. I'm not ashamed. I mean, really, I have a much stronger sense of self now. And, uh, anyways, it's really very temporary.
Oh. Tired of 'life in the fast lane'?
Wow, that really is great. In a few years, who knows, maybe they'll want to be in my documentary!

Well, sir, a lot has happened to the landscape of the suburban high school since I was a student, and I feel it would be a valuable, perhaps even enlightening endeavor, to chronicle the changes, to get intimate with the realities kids and parents face in American schools today.

Scooby and a few other students of different socioeconomic backgrounds.
